lom:description.lom:string:
"The undergraduate curriculum in MIT's Department of Materials Science and Engineering combines core topics, taken in the sophomore and junior years, with advanced elective subjects. The core topics include energetics of materials, materials structure and transformations, electronic, optical and magnetic properties, mechanical properties, organic and inorganic materials synthesis and properties, materials processing, and materials in society, both modern and ancient. The flexibility in the elective subjects allows students to tailor their academic programs to suit their interests in certain classes or applications of materials, for instance in biomaterials or in materials for the electronics industry. In addition, students perform a range of laboratory experiments and Thesis research as an integral part of their experience. The Department also offers a specialization in Archaeology and Materials for students with an interest in archaeological science.
The Bachelor of Science degree is ABET accredited and follows these Educational Objectives:
*
Provide a solid foundation in the fundamentals of the field of materials science and engineering *
Provide a balance between practical, industrial needs and a solid foundation in fundamentals in addressing engineering problems *
Provide an education that allows students to understand that materials are enabling and integral to the design and fabrication of engineering systems that serve society *
In recognition that contemporary graduates of DMSE often follow diverse career paths, provide education that prepares them to be lifelong learners *
Prepare students for positions of leadership in the field of materials science and engineering *
Provide state-of-the-art equipment and computational facilities in preparation of students for industrial and research careers."

lom:title.lom:string: Undergraduate Materials Science and Engineering Curriculum - MIT
